data.message:
The creator says it's a soft g. Sooo... it's his acronym. 

http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/22/tech/web/pronounce-gif/index.html

replies.message: The creator invented the gif, not acronyms, so he doesn't get to decide how it is pronounced. If he wanted to make that decision he should have given gifs an actual name.
He did give it a name. GIF with a soft g.
He is still incorrect, too bad he's not as smart as he seems for a man who came up with such a great idea.
How can he be wrong when English has very few hard-and-fast rules like how to pronounce such a word?

Anton Ljoljic he's pretty smart. I know, he's my dad. He knows how acronyms work. I think it's pretty hilarious how everyone thinks they are more knowledgeable about GIF, than the guy know created it.

The arguments against the creator are the dumbest arguments I've ever seen.
"He didnt create acronyms" okay but neither did the creator of SCUBA.
Every says SKOO-BA not SC-UH-BA.
"The creators incorrect because I say so" jesus christ you guys are like 5
And the creator can get out because graphic is pronounced g as gorilla
Brandon, its like you're not even reading. The comment *right above yours* talks about why that line of thinking is wrong.

Language belongs to its users. Eventually, there will be a standard. Whether it is hard or soft will depend on what happens in the future. The creator of a word or acronym can't control how it evolves over time. That is the will of the users.
Thanks for trying anyway. :) Must be cool to see your dad's invention used so prevalently.
Mozelle Toler Jif as in jiffy
